title: Alvin Bragg
content:
{{Short description|American lawyer and politician (born 1973)}}{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2022}}
{{Infobox officeholder
|name                = Alvin Bragg
|image               = Alvin Bragg-District Attorney for New York County-PXL 20230608 222746789 (cropped).jpg
|caption             = Bragg in 2023
|office              = 37th [[New York County District Attorney|District Attorney of New York County]]
|term_start          = January 1, 2022
|term_end            = 
|predecessor         = [[Cyrus Vance Jr.]]
|successor           = 
|birth_name          = Alvin Leonard Bragg Jr.
|birth_date          = {{birth date and age|1973|10|21}}
|birth_place         = [[New York City]], U.S.
|death_date          = 
|death_place         = 
|party               = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]]
|spouse              = {{marriage|Jamila Ponton|2003}}
|children            = 2
|education           = [[Harvard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]])
}}
'''Alvin Leonard Bragg Jr.''' (born October 21, 1973) is an American politician and lawyer who serves as the [[New York County District Attorney]], covering [[Manhattan]]. In [[2021 New York County District Attorney election|2021]], he became the first [[African American]] elected to that office.<ref name=electedDA>{{cite news |last1=Cline-Thomas |first1=Aundrea |title=Alvin Bragg Elected As Manhattan's First Black District Attorney |url=https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2021/11/02/voters-to-elect-new-manhattan-da-will-be-just-the-4th-person-to-hold-the-office-in-80-years/ |publisher=[[CBS News]], New York |date=November 2, 2021}}</ref> Bragg had previously served as Chief Deputy [[Attorney General of New York]] and as an Assistant [[United States Attorney]] in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]]. In 2024, he became the first and only district attorney to secure a [[Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York|conviction of a former United States president]].

==Early life and education==
Bragg was born in New York City on October 21, 1973. He hails from [[Harlem]], and grew up on [[St. Nicholas Historic District|Striver's Row]].<ref name=crimson/> In an interview with ''[[The American Prospect]]'', Bragg said that he had been "deeply affected by the criminal justice system – most directly through three gunpoint stops by the [[NYPD]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Khardori|first=Ankush|author-link=Ankush Khardori|date=July 13, 2021|title=Restorative Justice Requires an 'All-of-the-Above Approach'|url=https://prospect.org/api/content/0d13faec-e336-11eb-aea4-1244d5f7c7c6/|access-date=July 20, 2021|website=[[The American Prospect]]|language=en-us}}</ref> He graduated from the [[Trinity School (New York City)|Trinity School]]<ref name=wsj/> before attending [[Harvard College]]. 

He graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]], ''[[cum laude]]'', in 1995 with a major in government.<ref name="crimson">{{cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/1995/6/8/the-anointed-one-pon-the-evening/|title=The Anointed One: Students see Alvin Bragg as Conciliator|work=[[The Harvard Crimson]]|first=Anna D.|last=Wilde|date=June 8, 1995|accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref><ref name="patch">{{cite web|url=https://patch.com/new-york/washington-heights-inwood/manhattan-district-attorney-race-alvin-bragg-profile |title=Manhattan District Attorney Race: Alvin Bragg Profile|website=Patch.com|first=Gus |last=Saltonstall |date=June 16, 2021 |accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref> In 1999, he earned a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Harvard Law School]], where he was an editor of the ''[[Harvard Civil Rights–Civil Liberties Law Review]]''.<ref name="wsj">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/alvin-bragg-leans-on-harlem-roots-in-manhattan-district-attorney-race-11620576001|title=Alvin Bragg Leans on Harlem Roots in Manhattan District Attorney Race|first=Deanna |last=Paul |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=May 9, 2021|accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref><ref name="patch" /><ref>{{cite book |date=2003 |title=Martindale Hubbell Law Directory |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nCU8AQAAIAAJ&q=%22ALVIN+BRAGG+,+born+New+York+,+New+York+,+October+21+,+1973%22 |location=New Providence, NJ |publisher=Martindale-Hubbell Law Directory, Incorporated |page=NMP-995 |isbn=978-1-5616-0551-4 |via=[[Google Books]]}}</ref>

== Legal career ==
Bragg clerked for federal district judge [[Robert P. Patterson Jr.]] before he joined the law firm Morvillo Abramowitz Grand Iason & Anello as an [[Associate attorney|associate]], where his work focused on white collar fraud and civil rights issues. In 2003, he joined the office of the [[Attorney General of New York]] under [[Eliot Spitzer]] before becoming the chief of litigation and investigations for the [[New York City Council]]. In 2009, Bragg left the city council to serve as assistant [[United States Attorney]] in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite journal|first=Dan M.|last=Clark|url=https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/12/10/ny-chief-deputy-ag-heading-to-new-york-law-school-teaching-post/|title=NY Chief Deputy AG Heading to New York Law School Teaching Post|journal=[[New York Law Journal]]|publisher=[[ALM (company)|ALM]]|location=New York City|url-access=subscription|date=December 10, 2018|accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref>

In 2017, [[Eric Schneiderman]], then serving as attorney general, appointed Bragg Chief Deputy Attorney General of New York.<ref>{{cite web |date=September 18, 2017 |title=A.G. Schneiderman Announces Appointment Of New Chief Deputy Attorney General Alvin Bragg And Executive Deputy Attorney General Margaret Garnett | New York State Attorney General |url=https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/2017/ag-schneiderman-announces-appointment-new-chief-deputy-attorney-general-alvin |accessdate=June 23, 2021 |publisher=Ag.ny.gov}}</ref> Bragg ran the criminal justice and social justice divisions, overseeing lawsuits brought by the state against the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]], [[Harvey Weinstein]] and [[The Weinstein Company]], and the addition of a [[Department of Commerce v. New York|citizenship question]] on the [[2020 United States Census]]. 

He left the position in December 2018<ref name="nydaily" /> and became a professor at the [[New York Law School]], where he was co-director of the Racial Justice Project.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> Bragg is a member of the board of directors for [[The Legal Aid Society]]. He has represented the families of [[Ramarley Graham]] and [[Eric Garner]] in civil litigation against New York City.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hamm |first=Theodore |date=August 6, 2020 |title=A Life-Long Fight For Justice Spurred Alvin Bragg Into the Manhattan DA Race |url=https://indypendent.org/2020/08/a-life-long-fight-for-justice-spurred-alvin-bragg-into-the-manhattan-da-race/ |accessdate=June 23, 2021 |work=The Indypendent}}</ref>

==New York County District Attorney==
===2021 election===
{{Main|2021 New York County District Attorney election}}
In June 2019, Bragg started his candidacy for the 2021 Democratic Party nomination for [[New York County District Attorney]], then held by [[Cyrus Vance Jr.]], who did not run for reelection.<ref name="nydaily">{{cite web|url=https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/ny-alvin-bragg-democratic-primary-campaign-manhattan-da-cy-vance-20190618-r2faz5bpw5a4ldnkxlodx7mrfy-story.html|title=Alvin Bragg announces Democratic primary campaign against Manhattan DA Cy Vance|first=Anna|last=Sanders|work=[[The New York Daily News]]|date=June 18, 2019|accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://politi.co/3xN67Me|title=Former federal prosecutor close to winning Manhattan DA primary|first=Erin|last=Durkin|website=[[Politico|Politico PRO]]|date=June 23, 2021}}</ref> Bragg ran as a supporter of [[criminal justice reform]] measures, and his campaign was characterized as one of the "campaigns of progressive prosecutors across the country".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Walsh |first=James D. |date=2021-07-02 |title=Alvin Bragg Set to Become Manhattan's First Black District Attorney |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/07/manhattan-district-attorney-results-alvin-bragg-wins.html |access-date=2023-08-12 |website=[[New York (magazine)|New York Intelligencer]]|language=en-us}}</ref>

His candidacy received the endorsement of ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-05-27 |title=Opinion {{!}} Alvin Bragg for Manhattan D.A. (Published 2021) |work=[[The New York Times]] |language=en-US |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/27/opinion/alvin-bragg-for-manhattan-da.html |access-date=2023-08-12}}</ref> Following the June 22, 2021 Democratic primary, Bragg led in the reported vote count and [[Tali Farhadian Weinstein]] conceded the primary to Bragg on July 2.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/02/nyregion/alvin-bragg-district-attorney-trump.html |title=Bragg Set to Be Manhattan's Next D.A., and a Potential Trump Scourge |work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Jonah E.|last=Bromwich |date=June 22, 2021 |accessdate=July 2, 2021}}</ref> On November 2, 2021, Bragg defeated Republican Thomas Kenniff in the general election, becoming the first African-American to be elected New York County District Attorney.<ref name="electedDA" />

=== Tenure ===
Bragg was sworn into office on January 1, 2022.<ref>{{cite news|first=Caroline|last=Vakil|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/587857-first-black-manhattan-da-sworn-in-to-take-over-trump-case |title=First Black Manhattan DA sworn in, to take over Trump case |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=January 1, 2022 |accessdate=January 22, 2022}}</ref>

==== Policies on low-level offenses ====
On January 4, 2022, after three days in office, he announced that his office would no longer prosecute low-level offenses such as [[fare evasion]], resisting arrest, [[Prostitution in the United States|prostitution]], and [[Cannabis in the United States|cannabis]]-related misdemeanors unless accompanied by a [[felony]] charge. He also decided to seek lesser charges for burglaries and store robberies where the offender "displays a dangerous instrument but does not create a genuine risk of physical harm".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2022/01/04/manhattan-da-alvin-bragg-low-level-offenses/ |title=Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg Says His Office Won't Prosecute Fare Evasion, Resisting Arrest, Prostitution And More Without Accompanying Felony Charge|website=[[CBS New York]]|date=January 5, 2022 |accessdate=January 22, 2022}}</ref> On January 20, Bragg disputed what he described was a "legalistic" interpretation of his prosecution policy memo and indicated that he supported a [[zero tolerance]] policy for violent crimes.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/ny-manhattan-da-alvin-bragg-clarifies-confusing-day-one-memo-20220120-gj2ifc7f55cbfnrsuebdgoice4-story.html|title=Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg says he's not soft on violent crime, clarifies 'legalistic' memo that outlined prosecution policies|first=Noah|last=Goldberg|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=January 20, 2022|accessdate=January 20, 2022}}</ref>

==== Donald Trump prosecution ====
{{Main|New York criminal investigation of The Trump Organization|Prosecution of Donald Trump in New York}}
On February 23, 2022, [[Carey R. Dunne]] and [[Mark F. Pomerantz]], the lead prosecutors in the New York County District Attorney's investigation into [[Donald Trump]] and his businesses, resigned abruptly after Bragg "indicated to them that he had doubts about moving forward with a case against Mr. Trump".<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Rashbaum|first1=William K.|last2=Protess|first2=Ben|last3=Bromwich|first3=Jonah E.|last4=Christobek|first4=Kate|last5=Schweber|first5=Nate|date=February 23, 2022|title=2 Prosecutors Leading N.Y. Trump Inquiry Resign, Clouding Case's Future|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/23/nyregion/trump-ny-fraud-investigation.html|access-date=February 24, 2022|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> In his letter of resignation, Pomerantz wrote that the "team that has been investigating Mr. Trump harbors no doubt about whether he committed crimes,<ref name="MFPLetter">{{Cite news |date=March 23, 2022|title=Read the Full Text of Mark Pomerantz's Resignation Letter |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/23/nyregion/mark-pomerantz-resignation-letter.html |access-date=March 24, 2022 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>  including [[falsifying business records]], and that it was "a grave failure of justice"<ref name="MFPLetter"/> not to pursue criminal charges.<ref name="NYTTrumpArticle">{{Cite news |last1=Rashbaum |first1=William K. |last2=Protess |first2=Ben |last3=Bromwich |first3=Jonah E. |date=March 23, 2022 |title=Trump Is Guilty of 'Numerous' Felonies, Prosecutor Who Resigned Says |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/23/nyregion/trump-investigation-felony-resignation-pomerantz.html |access-date=2022-03-23 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> 

''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Bragg "balked at pursuing an indictment against Mr. Trump" and lacked confidence proving in court that Trump "knowingly falsified the value of his assets on annual financial statements".<ref name="NYTTrumpArticle" /> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' noted that Bragg was slow to meet with Dunne and Pomerantz after taking office and when they finally met to discuss the case, a source in the D.A.'s Office commented that Bragg seemed distracted and disengaged, continually checking his cell phone (allegations Bragg's spokesperson denied).<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/why-does-new-yorks-criminal-investigation-of-donald-trump-appear-all-but-over|title=Why Does New York's Criminal Investigation of Donald Trump Appear All But Over? After promising to prioritize the case, the new Manhattan District Attorney, Alvin Bragg, seems to have abandoned it|magazine=[[The New Yorker]]|first=Jane|last=Mayer|author-link=Jane Mayer|date=February 24, 2022|access-date=February 26, 2022}}</ref>

On November 21, 2022, ''The New York Times'' reported that the district attorney's office "has moved to jump-start its criminal investigation" into Trump's reported "hush-money payment to a porn star who said she had an affair with Mr. Trump".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/21/nyregion/trump-bragg-stormy-daniels.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare |title=Manhattan Prosecutors Move to Jump-Start Criminal Inquiry Into Trump |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 21, 2022 |access-date=November 25, 2022 |archive-date=November 25, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221125020504/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/21/nyregion/trump-bragg-stormy-daniels.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare |url-status=live |last1=Bromwich |first1=Jonah E. |last2=Protess |first2=Ben |last3=Rashbaum |first3=William K. }}</ref> Bragg confirmed to [[CNN]] in January 2023 that the probe was ongoing.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Scannell |first1=Kara |first2=Devan|last2= Cole|date=2023-01-13 |title=Manhattan DA Alvin Bragg tells CNN that his office's investigation of Trump Org. will continue {{!}} CNN Politics |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/01/13/politics/trump-organization-investigation-timeline-alvin-bragg/index.html |access-date=2023-03-10 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref> On January 30, the office presented evidence to a grand jury regarding Trump's role in the payment.<ref>{{cite web |last=O'Connor |first=Lydia |date=2023-01-30 |title=Manhattan DA Investigating Trump To Present Evidence To Grand Jury: Report |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-stormy-daniels-manhattan-da_n_63d80565e4b07c0c7e050a5d |access-date=2023-01-30 |website=[[HuffPost]]|language=en}}</ref> Trump was indicted on March 30<ref>{{cite web|last=Scannell |first=Kara |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/03/30/politics/donald-trump-indictment/index.html |title=Donald Trump indicted by Manhattan grand jury on more than 30 counts related to business fraud | CNN Politics |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=2023-03-31 |accessdate=2023-04-04}}</ref> and arraigned on April 4; it was the first indictment of a former president in United States history.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kates |first=Graham |date=2023-03-31 |title=Trump indicted in Manhattan, becoming first ex-president charged with a crime |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-indicted-in-manhattan-first-ex-president-to-be-charged-with-a-crime/ |access-date=2023-06-10 |website=[[CBS News]] |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Linton |first=Caroline |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-arraignment-manhattan-district-attorney-alvin-bragg-holds-briefing-watch-live/ |title=Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg says "thorough investigation" led to Trump indictment |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=1927-09-18 |accessdate=2023-04-04}}</ref> Trump pleaded not guilty.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/04/04/politics/donald-trump-arraignment-new-york/index.html | title=Donald Trump pleads not guilty to 34 felony counts of falsifying business records | CNN Politics | website=[[CNN]] | date=April 4, 2023 }}</ref> Trump was found guilty of all counts on May 30, 2024, making Bragg the first prosecutor in U.S. history to win a conviction against a former president.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2024/05/30/nyregion/trump-trial-verdict|title=Update from Jonah Bromwich|date=May 30, 2024|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>

==== Jose Alba prosecution ====
On July 7, 2022, Jose Alba, a 61-year-old [[Bodega (store)|bodega]] clerk, was attacked by customer Austin Simon in a dispute over a bag of potato chips. Alba attempted to de-escalate, but after being cornered behind the counter and being shoved into a wall, defended himself with a knife, killing the assailant.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |last=Cunnington |first=Jessica |date=July 12, 2022 |title=New Video Shows Girlfriend Stab NYC Bodega Worker After Confrontation Turned Deadly |url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/new-video-shows-girlfriend-stab-nyc-bodega-worker-after-confrontation-turned-deadly/3769959/ |access-date=July 12, 2022 |website=[[WNBC]] |language=en-US}}</ref> Police who investigated the incident described Alba's actions as self defense.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/nyc-bodega-owner-arrested-for-self-defense-stabbing-ny-only/3759627/ | title=NYC Bodega Owner Arrested for Self-Defense Stabbing | date=July 2, 2022 }}</ref> 

Bragg, in his [[prosecutorial discretion]], charged Alba with murder and requested bail at $500,000. The judge initially set bail at $250,000, before lowering it to $50,000.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/08/nyregion/bodega-stabbing-jose-alba.html Adams Shows Support for Man Charged in Bodega Killing That Caused Outcry], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref> The dead attacker's girlfriend also stabbed Alba with her own knife, after attempting to turn Alba's knife back on him. Bragg declined to charge her.<ref name=":0" /> After backlash, including from [[Mayor of New York City|Mayor]] [[Eric Adams]] who said Alba was acting in self defense, Bragg ultimately dropped the charges against Alba, noting that "a homicide case against Alba could not be proven at trial beyond a reasonable doubt".<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-07-19 |title=Bodega Clerk Who Fatally Stabbed Man Will Not Face Charges |language=en-US |work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/19/nyregion/jose-alba-bodega-charges-nyc.html|access-date=2022-07-19}}</ref>

==== Steve Bannon prosecution ====
On September 6, 2022, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that [[Steve Bannon]] would be indicted on September 8 by Bragg's prosecutors on the same charges of fraud that he was [[Federal pardons in the United States|federally pardoned]] for by then-President Trump in 2020.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Jacobs |first1=Shayna |last2=Alemany |first2=Jacqueline |author-link2=Jacqueline Alemany |last3=Dawsey |first3=Josh |author-link3=Josh Dawsey |date=September 6, 2022 |title=Steve Bannon faces state indictment in N.Y., will surrender Thursday |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2022/09/06/bannon-border-wall-indictment/ |access-date=September 7, 2022 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> On September 8, Bannon was charged with "defrauding Americans who wanted to contribute to construction of a southern border wall, resurrecting a threat that Mr. Bannon seemed to have escaped with a 2021 presidential pardon"; Bannon pleaded not guilty.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/09/08/nyregion/bannon-indictment-new-york.html|title=Bannon Pleads Not Guilty to New York Charges in Wall Case|last1=Marcius|first1=Chelsia Rose|last2=Bromwich|first2=Jonah E.|last3=O'Brien|first3=Rebecca Davis|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 September 2022|orig-date=Originally published 8 September 2022|url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Freifeld |first=Karen |date=9 September 2022 |title=Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser, pleads not guilty in border wall scheme |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/steve-bannon-surrender-thursday-face-new-york-indictment-2022-09-08/ |work=[[Reuters]] |access-date=17 April 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=8 September 2022 |title=Steve Bannon, charged with money laundering, pleads not guilty in ‘We Build the Wall’ scheme |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2022/09/08/steve-bannon-charged-with-money-laundering-pleads-not-guilty-in-we-build-the-wall-scheme/ |work=[[The Chicago Tribune]] |access-date=17 April 2024}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Bragg married Jamila Marie Ponton in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/02/style/weddings-celebrations-jamila-ponton-alvin-bragg-jr.html |title=WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Jamila Ponton, Alvin Bragg Jr. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 2, 2003 |accessdate=June 23, 2021}}</ref> They have two children.<ref name=patch/> Bragg at one time taught Sunday School at the [[Abyssinian Baptist Church]].<ref name="We Support Alvin">{{cite web | title=About | website=We Support Alvin | url=https://www.alvinbragg.com/about | access-date=2023-03-23}}</ref>
